speaker: Frasier
text: When the phone company says they will be at your door between the  hours of nine and noon, they have entered into a verbal contract.  If they show up at 12:47 they are in breach of said contract.  _Niles is shown to be carrying a birdcage on his lap.  He is looking weary.  Apparently he has been listening to Frasier rant for the entire drive._

speaker: Niles
text: [_with irritation_] Again, I agree.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I just shouldn't have waited for them, that's all.  Now my  entire day is thrown off.

speaker: Niles
text: Still, I appreciate your taking the time to give me a lift.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well, when you informed me you had to get to the promenade shops  posthaste, I assumed it was an actual emergency - not to return a  cage for some silly lovebirds.

speaker: Niles
text: It may not be on the order of a fallen pant cuff, but until I get  home with something more secure, little Daphne and Niles are living  under a colander.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dear God... don't tell me you actually named them after yourselves.

speaker: Niles
text: Big mistake, I admit.  This morning when Daphne escaped, I just kept  thinking, What if she's hurt or lost or eaten by a cat?  Or worse...  what if she meets a bird who's more birdly than Niles but without the  substance?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_sardonically_] Trust me. No one is more birdly than Niles.

speaker: Niles
text: Thanks.

speaker: Frasier
text: What is with all this traffic?  I tell you, don't these people have  jobs?  Some of us have a radio show to do!

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, relax, you're not on for another hour and a half.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_looking at the car clock_] That can't be right. [_checks his watch_]  Oh, Dear God!  My show's on in fifteen minutes!

speaker: Niles
text: I had no idea it was so late.  You can just drop me out front.  I'll  get a cab home.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm afraid I'll have to.  Damn it!  Dad did this.  I tell you, he  gets in here, he wants to hear his favorite radio station and starts  pushing buttons like a lab rat on amphetamines!  _Frasier quickly turns around the gate post and toward the exit gate.  He pulls  up and speaks to George, the lot attendant._

speaker: Frasier
text: Excuse me, we've changed our minds.  We won't be parking.

speaker: George
text: Two dollars.

speaker: Frasier
text: No, you see, we just came in for a second and decided not to park.  Just  check the time on the ticket.

speaker: George
text: It's two dollars for any portion of twenty minutes - one second, ten  minutes, whatever.  Unless you go over, then it's two more dollars.

speaker: Frasier
text: Forgive me, perhaps I'm not being clear.  You see, I mistakenly pulled in  here, decided not to park, and now I'd like to just get out.

speaker: George
text: Two dollars.

speaker: Niles
text: I have two dollars.

speaker: Frasier
text: Put that away!

speaker: George
text: Sorry.  You come in, you pay.  That's policy.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, really?  It just so happens that I have a few policies of my own, and  one of them is that I do not pay good money for nothing!

speaker: George
text: Well, not for nothing, but your car's taking up space on the property.

speaker: Frasier
text: That's not parking!

speaker: George
text: It looks parked to me.

speaker: Frasier
text: But it's been continually in motion!

speaker: George
text: It's stopped.

speaker: Frasier
text: But it's still running.

speaker: George
text: It's parked.  Look, the fee is two dollars.  There's nothing you can do.    _At hearing those words, Frasier gets that look he always does when he fancies he's  just had a brilliant idea._

speaker: Frasier
text: Is that so? [_to Niles_] Do you hear that?

speaker: Niles
text: [_nervous upon seeing the look_] Yes, and it makes sense to me.

speaker: Frasier
text: Fine.  Have it your way.

speaker: Niles
text: [_scared_] What are we doing, Frasier?

speaker: Frasier
text: If I'm going to be paying for parking, we are going to get our twenty  minutes' worth.    _Behind Frasier, cars start to honk as they are stopped up in the exit lane.    FADE OUT_    **THE TERRIER PUZZLES**  _Scene Two - Apartment  Martin is sitting on the couch doing a jigsaw puzzle with Eddie beside him._

speaker: Martin
text: OK, what we need now is a side piece with some ear and a little bit of sky.  Ear with sky... ear with sky...

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, this is it.  Sorry it's taken me so long to pick up the last of my  things.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, no problem.  Frasier's not having the carpet people here til Friday.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, really?  When it was my room, he said the carpet's good for another  twenty years.

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, well, now it's going to be a reading sanctuary.

speaker: Daphne
text: He's turning my room into a library?

speaker: Martin
text: No, he made it very clear it was a "reading sanctuary."  A library implies  sharing.  I think there are some pieces missing from this one.

speaker: Daphne
text: You always say that, keep looking.

speaker: Martin
text: Why do I even do this stupid thing?  Some puzzle, there's a picture of  what's it's going to look like right on the box!

speaker: Daphne
text: You always say that, too.

speaker: Daphne
text: What's wrong, Eddie?

speaker: Martin
text: Come, boy! [_Eddie keeps barking_] He must know you're moving.  He gets this  way whenever I bring out my suitcase.  He knows I'm going away and he  starts raising hell.  Boy, come! [_Eddie keeps barking_] Yeah, that's what it  looks like.

speaker: Daphne
text: [_puts the box down_] Well, there's nothing to get upset about.  I'll be here  every day for your physical therapy.

speaker: Martin
text: You hear that, boy?  She'll be here every day to torture your master.

speaker: Daphne
text: What should I do?

speaker: Martin
text: Maybe it'd distract him if you made me lunch.  _Daphne gives him a look.    FADE OUT    Scene Three - Parking Garage  Frasier and Niles are still encamped before the exit gate.  A line of cars is  stopped behind Frasier, honking.  George is directing them one by one out  through the entrance lane._

speaker: George
text: [_as another car tries to enter_] Hold it, man!   Woman in Car: [_as she's passing, to Frasier_] Dumbass!

speaker: Niles
text: Other motorists are getting angry.

speaker: Frasier
text: If they weren't so shortsighted, they'd see that I'm doing this for their  own good.  It's like correcting people's grammar - I don't do it to be  popular.

speaker: Niles
text: And I support that, but in this case I strongly feel we should pay the  money and get out of here before there's violence.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, they can get around us if they want to.  So what, it takes them an  extra two seconds!  It's a small price to pay for making this a better world.

speaker: Niles
text: OK, but we're also inconveniencing ourselves.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, you'll get home to your stupid, filthy bird soon enough!

speaker: Niles
text: I meant that your radio show is about to start... dumbass.

speaker: Frasier
text: Right.  _Cut to - KACL  Roz is waiting in her booth.  Kenny rushes in._

speaker: Kenny
text: Where the hell's the doc?

speaker: Roz
text: He still isn't here.

speaker: Kenny
text: It's almost showtime!  I swear to God, nobody here has any discipline!  I'm  starting to think, I've been too loose with the leash!  I mean, gee whiz, I  try to make everyone happy and all it gets me is a twisted gut.  Well, no  more!  This Saturday, we're gonna have a staff meeting, we're gonna hash out  some rules!

speaker: Roz
text: I'm busy Saturday!

speaker: Kenny
text: [_pause_] Well, it's not mandatory.

speaker: Roz
text: Roz Doyle.  Frasier!  Where are you?  What? [_to Kenny_] He's at some mall, he's  still got ten minutes of parking left. [_into phone_] You know, you don't have  to use the full twenty minutes.

speaker: Roz
text: [_to Kenny_] He knows that. [_into phone_] What are you doing? [_beat_] What?!  You  lost me after "Gandhi."

speaker: Frasier
text: Just stall.  I don't know, read some fan mail if you have to.  There must  be!  Check in my Inbox!  Oh, never mind!  I'll be there when I get there,  and when I do, I will have a little speech for my listeners about the  Power of One! [_hangs up_]

speaker: Niles
text: [_sarcastic_] Sounds like everybody's a winner today.

speaker: Frasier
text: Are you being snide?  Because that's not healthy.

speaker: Niles
text: [_fed up_] Well, I'll just go return my birdcage. [_opens car door_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles!  You shut that door! [_he does_] You can't desert me in the middle of  a fight!

speaker: Niles
text: I'm not deserting you.

speaker: Frasier
text: It would appear to others that you are, thereby weakening my position.  Please, you must stay.

speaker: Man
text: What the hell is going on here?

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm glad you asked me that question.  I am making a stand against this  garage that holds me, my passenger, and my automobile hostage for a  parking fee which I do not owe.

speaker: George
text: [_to Man_] He don't want to pay two dollars.

speaker: Frasier
text: Look, I already told you, it's not about the money.  In fact, to prove it's  not about the money, I will donate two dollars to the charity of your  choice.

speaker: Man
text: Only rich people have time for this kind of crap!  Just pay the two bucks,  Mr.-BMW!

speaker: Frasier
text: My income, and the style of car which I drive, are irrelevant!  Isn't that  so, Niles?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, I drive a Mercedes, and I would have paid ten minutes ago.

speaker: George
text: I told my boss I have a non-pay.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh!  You see, Niles, this happens so often they actually have a name for  us.

speaker: Niles
text: More than one, I bet.

speaker: George
text: [_holds out a clipboard_] Just sign the form that says, "unable to pay," and  send us a check.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I'm certainly not going to send you a check.

speaker: George
text: Look, most people don't, just sign the form so I can get this gate open.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, Frasier, it's an out!  You should take it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, I refuse to sign anything that says I am unable to pay!  It's  untrue!

speaker: George
text: Look, I really don't care, Jack, I just got to get this lane re-opened.  Now it's either two dollars or the form, so I can put it in my drawer.

speaker: Frasier
text: You know my terms: you will receive your money when the twenty minutes is  up.

speaker: George
text: Fine.  Then I'll put in my own money! [_reaches for it_]

speaker: Frasier
text: No, no, you can't do that!

speaker: George
text: It's too late, it's on me!  [_opens gate_] Go ahead, Mr. Beemer!

speaker: Frasier
text: Don't you call me that!  You put that down right now, we're not going  anywhere!

speaker: Niles
text: [_can take no more_] AAAAHHHH!!!  I can't do this anymore, Frasier!

speaker: Frasier
text: Excuse me. [_rolls window up_] What are you talking about?

speaker: Niles
text: Do you really want justice?  Or is this just an outlet for your bad mood?

speaker: Frasier
text: I AM NOT IN A BAD MOOD! [_Niles looks at him_] Oh fine, just go!  And bravo  for staying on a whole ten minutes!  Goodbye!

speaker: George
text: I don't blame you for bailing on that idiot.

speaker: Niles
text: He's not an idiot.  He's just... passionate.

speaker: George
text: I think he's an idiot. [_to Frasier_] Suit yourself, idiot.

speaker: Niles
text: That idiot happens to be my brother.  _Niles bends down to look at Frasier through the window, then gets back  in the car.  Frasier gives him a grateful nod.  Niles nods back.    END OF ACT ONE    ACT TWO    Scene Four - Garage  By now a group of half a dozen angry people is standing behind Frasier's car,  yelling._

speaker: Frasier
text: Don't these people realize I'm on their side?

speaker: Niles
text: I don't think they care, so long as you're in their lane.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_out his window_] I'm doing this for all of you!  Don't you understand?

speaker: Man 2
text: No, no, come out here and explain it to us!

speaker: Niles
text: Don't even think about it, Frasier, that man wants to hit you.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm not afraid.  _He does not, however, get out of the car.  Instead, he rolls open the sunroof  and sticks his head up through it, turning around to face the angry crowd._

speaker: Frasier
text: People, please!  I am not the enemy!  I am your champion!

speaker: Man 2
text: Well, we got places to be, so move yo' ass!

speaker: Man 2
text: Yeah, move it!

speaker: Frasier
text: But I'm doing this for all of us!

speaker: Woman 3
text: If you want to do something for me, get out of the way!

speaker: Man 2
text: You save the protest for your own driveway!

speaker: Frasier
text: If you could only see things from my point of view, then I'm sure you'd  agree with me!  You see, I pulled into this garage, decided not to park,  and now I want to leave, but they still insist on collecting two dollars!  Is that fair?  Has a service been provided?

speaker: Woman 3
text: Even if it's a rip-off, it's better than causing a big stink!

speaker: Frasier
text: Ah!  But is it?  I say no!  I say we've been trod upon long enough by  people who are supposed to be providing our services!  By the postmen who  mix up our deliveries!  By the telephone repairmen who swear to be there  between nine and noon, and yet arrive at-

speaker: Frasier
text: -12:47, when you're wearing nothing but a towel and a hatful of shampoo!  Well, ENOUGH!  I invoke my right to peaceful protest!  Civil disobedience  is a cornerstone of this country, for it is how the common man is heard!  _Behind Frasier, in the entrance lane, George confers with a tow truck driver  that has just arrived._

speaker: George
text: Can you tow it?

speaker: Driver
text: Not with them in it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, that's just tough luck!  Because we ain't budging.

speaker: Driver
text: You'll have to call the police.  Crowd: Good idea!/It's about time!/Yeah!

speaker: Frasier
text: GO AHEAD! [_sits back down and closes the sunroof_] I think I made a  mistake.

speaker: Niles
text: Maybe it's time to back down.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'm not sure that I can.  I am right, after all.  My principles are  holding me captive.

speaker: Niles
text: Your principles may have started this, but it's your rigidity that's kept  it going.

speaker: Frasier
text: My rigidity?  The rigid ones are the ones who operate this garage, and  enforce such inflexible policies.

speaker: Niles
text: You've been given more than one opportunity to leave without paying!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, but that's not the point!  They have to know why I won't pay.

speaker: Niles
text: Which you could explain in a letter!  But no, you won't be satisfied until  everyone either agrees with you, or has suffered for failing to!

speaker: Frasier
text: Do you really think so?

speaker: Niles
text: I do.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well... that's quite an indictment.  I never really thought of myself as  uncompromising.  Well, not in a bad way.  I'm not sure I like this side of  myself.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, you can still change course.  If you can leave here without getting  your full twenty minutes' worth, you'll be the bigger person for it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, but then these taunting motorists won't know that I'm being the  bigger person.  They'll think they've gotten the better of me, or that I'm  afraid to be arrested.

speaker: Niles
text: The bigger person doesn't worry about what other people think.

speaker: Frasier
text: Damn! [_sulky_] I DO want to be the bigger person, it's just so hard!  [_pause_] You know, we wouldn't be in this mess if it weren't for you and  that ridiculous birdcage!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, come on, I can only change one character flaw at a time!  _Scene Five - Apartment  Martin and Daphne are sitting on the couch, playing with Eddie._

speaker: Daphne
text: You were right about distracting him, he seems fine now.

speaker: Martin
text: As soon as you head for that door again, he's gonna have a fit.  Let me get  you some dog treats to give him.  _He heads for the kitchen.  As soon as he's gone, Eddie jumps down and paws at the box  Daphne was carrying._

speaker: Daphne
text: I don't understand.  I may sleep across town, but I still see him all the  time.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, you got to look at it from Eddie's point of view.  This person who's  meant so much to him isn't going to be living here anymore.  _As he speaks from the kitchen, Daphne looks inside the box and finds one of  Eddie's toy tennis balls.  Eddie jumps at it._

speaker: Martin
text: For nine years, he's felt the comfort of knowing you were here every night,  and making him his breakfast every morning, and he's come to depend on  that.  Now everything's changed.  _Daphne smiles to herself and tosses Eddie the tennis ball.  He scampers away  happily as Martin comes out of the kitchen._

speaker: Martin
text: Ah, would you look at that.  He's probably gonna get on my bed to pout.

speaker: Daphne
text: I think he'll adjust.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, who knows?  Old dogs get used to a certain routine.  And as tough as  they might look, they get lonely.  Well, I guess he'll adjust eventually.  [_sits back down to the puzzle_]

speaker: Daphne
text: You know, maybe I haven't been coming around enough lately.  Why don't you  and I make a regular appointment to walk him together?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, geez, that'd be great!  I have to check with him, but he's free most of  the time.

speaker: Daphne
text: Why don't we start tomorrow morning? [_opens the door_] That way I can have  breakfast with the old boy too.

speaker: Martin
text: He'd really like that.  _Daphne smiles and leaves.    Scene Six - KACL  The show has started and Roz is reading from a paper._

speaker: Roz
text: Then, on Friday, it'll be fish sticks with tater tots and a fruit cup.  That  takes care of the St. Victoria's Elementary lunch schedule for the next month.  We'll be back to tackle St. Victor's, after this!

speaker: Kenny
text: Holy buckets, what are you doing?!  Take some calls!

speaker: Roz
text: I'm not a shrink, I can't tell people what to do!

speaker: Kenny
text: Yeah, that always stops you women.  Just rap about something, open up a  discussion, you know? [_checks wall_] The station I.D.'s over, go!

speaker: Roz
text: Oh, OK! [_back on the air_] Hello again, everybody!  Well, we're still waiting  on Dr. Crane.  So, until he gets here, let's hear what's on your minds!  You  know the number, give me a call. [_presses button_] Hello, caller.  You're on  the air.

speaker: Mark
text: [_v.o._] Hi, Roz.  This is Mark from Bainbridge, and I made a big mistake.  _Roz, feeling confident, puts her feet up on the desk, and even imitates  Frasier's pompous intonation._

speaker: Roz
text: Go on.

speaker: Mark
text: I slept with my boss.  Now things at work are super uncomfortable.

speaker: Roz
text: Well, Mark, I feel for you.  I've been there myself.  What you ought to do  is just talk it out with your boss.

speaker: Mark
text: You went through this too?

speaker: Roz
text: Yeah, and it was weird for a while, but now, things are just fine.  [_chuckles_] Who else out there needs my advice?  Let me hear your calls.  [_presses button_] You're on the air.  How can I solve your problem?

speaker: Sheila
text: [_v.o._] Actually, I was calling about something else, but when you say,  "now things are fine," it sounds like you still work with this person.

speaker: Roz
text: What?  No, no! [_laughs nervously_] I worked with this person a long, long  time ago.

speaker: Sheila
text: Then why'd you say "now"?

speaker: Roz
text: Because... I don't speak so good?

speaker: Sheila
text: Isn't Dr. Crane your boss?

speaker: Roz
text: Well, no, I like to think of Frasier as a "colleague."

speaker: Sheila
text: Oh, now he's "Frasier"!

speaker: Roz
text: Yeah, I mean, it's just that I...

speaker: Sheila
text: I think you did Frasier.  _Roz drops her feet off the desk.    Scene Seven - Garage  Niles is still trying to convince Frasier._

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, you are not a prisoner of your character.  You can decide right  now that you're going to be the flexible one here.  Pay the money, and go!

speaker: Frasier
text: I could break my pattern.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes!

speaker: Frasier
text: I could just pay the money, without proving to everyone that I'm right,  without teaching them a lesson.

speaker: Niles
text: Exactly!  You can do it!

speaker: Frasier
text: Sir?  I'll have you know, I am leaving, with time to spare.

speaker: George
text: Congratulations.

speaker: Frasier
text: Since you cannot understand the moral code for which I stayed here, I am  sure you must be perplexed that I am leaving before the twenty minutes is  up.  Suffice it to say, I am the bigger man for it.  And you, and your  nefarious policy may now carry on, in what is highway robbery in the  truest sense of the expression!  Here is your ticket, and... [_hands over  ticket and money_] your ill-gotten two dollars.  _George takes the money and the ticket.  Frasier starts the car, but instead of  raising the gate, George flips the sign in his window from "$2.00" to "$4.00."_

speaker: George
text: Four dollars.

speaker: Frasier
text: Four dollars?!

speaker: George
text: You went over twenty minutes.  It's two dollars for each portion of twenty  minutes.

speaker: Frasier
text: But I already backed down!

speaker: George
text: Well, if you had spared me the speech, you would have made it out in time.  [_smiles_] Tough break, huh?

speaker: Frasier
text: Indeed... hold on, Niles.  _Niles, scared again, huddles down in his seat.  Frasier floors it, plowing  through the gate and snapping off the bar as he exits.    Scene Eight - KACL  Roz has spiraled into Hell.  On one side she faces a board lit up with  incoming calls, while Kenny hovers nosily behind her.    Outside in the hall, dozens of staffers are massed like hyenas outside the  booth, peering in and gossiping among themselves._

speaker: Kenny
text: I can't believe it!  I mean, I always felt some chemistry between you and  the doc, but... Wowza!  This can't hurt ratings.

speaker: Roz
text: Calm down, Kenny, it isn't true!

speaker: Kenny
text: [_laughing_] Yeah, right.  Hey, you didn't do it here at the station, did you?

speaker: Roz
text: Of course not!

speaker: Kenny
text: Hey, as long as it wasn't on my couch, who gives?  Hey, the commercial's  over.

speaker: Roz
text: [_back on-air_] And we're back, with our new topic: Cats or Dogs, which is  better?  _As she takes the next call, Frasier rushes into his booth and takes his  position._

speaker: Roz
text: Hello, caller, you're on the air.

speaker: Jerry
text: [_v.o._] This is Jerry from Elliot Bay.

speaker: Roz
text: Which do you have, Jerry: cat or a dog? [_hits cough button_] Frasier, I am  so sorry, I really screwed up!

speaker: Frasier
text: It's all right, Roz.  I'll take care of everything.

speaker: Jerry
text: I don't have either, I just want to know what's going on with Dr. Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_on-air_] Yes, well I'll bet you do, Jerry!  Dr. Frasier Crane here,  Seattle.  I'm sorry I'm late.  It sounds as if Roz has informed you of my  exploits!

speaker: Jerry
text: She hasn't said much, but we'd like to hear it from you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, it wasn't my finest hour.  Let's just say that I got in there,  realized I made a mistake, and then tried like hell to get out!

speaker: Roz
text: [_waving urgently_] Frasier!  _Frasier waves her off, not noticing the staffers exploding with excitement  behind him._

speaker: Frasier
text: There was a lot of shouting, and then a line started to form behind me.  Fortunately, my brother was with me for moral support, and, well, let's  face it, somebody to talk to.  You know, you'd be amazed how long twenty  minutes can be when you're watching the clock.  At least, in the end, I  got out of there without paying the four dollars!  _He gives a self-congratulatory chuckle, and looks at Roz.  Her head is buried  on her console.    END OF ACT TWO_
